title: Sona is an outdated and thus flawed character design.
body:
I'm not even going to point to her clear issues (mobility, low health, etc..).  I would just like to address the fact that her kit is for all intents and purposes designed to function at 50%+ CDR..... Or with a metric ton of AP.   Honestly play her in like 3 games and tell me she doesn't feel clunky and useless till you meet one of those two requirements.  Yeah i get it everyone needs some built in weakness, that they can over come via whatever, but that weakness should not be fucking max CDR and/or 2 full built AP items on a support.

And what really gets me is i'm sure that Riot knows she needs to be updated to fit what the game has become, but "fixing" her is such a low priority.  She feels like the metaphorical squeaky door hinge that you were going to deal with till the basement flooded, then the stove broke, then you had to deal with a insect infestation, etc...  You want to fix the issue, but there is just so much more important stuff to deal with, and it's not like a squeaky door hinge is going to ruin your day.


I would also like to point out that her offensive support (non ultimate) "thing" is probably the least meaningful one in the game.   To be more clear as to what i mean, imagine you got hit by Sona AA+Q+ empowered AA.  Now how do you feel compared to when you get hit by ANY other 'supports' primary offensive ability;  IE {{champion:412}} 's hook, {{champion:267}} 's bubble, {{champion:99}} 's root, {{champion:117}} 's polymorph, {{champion:497}} knock up.

...no

Athene's is blatant healing. Healing is universal. I didn't say "Ardent".
ADCs exist to take CS, complain, and be a useful distraction as they frantically try to farm under tower due to mistakenly thinking Ashe E is a waveclear tool.

Statistically, Sona has the highest winrate for supports in Platinum elo and higher. The major problem a lot of people face when playing her is trying to play her like any other support, when she has clear weaknesses that make her not able to be played like any other support. People assume that just because she has a pokey Q like Nami's W or Lulu's Q that she needs to move as far up as them to get poke, but the difference is both Nami's W and Lulu's Q are long range and both Nami and Lulu have a way to prevent taking damage when poking. People assume that just because she has a strong heal/shield like Soraka/Thresh that they need to spam it to protect the ADC. People assume that just because she has a movement speed increase like Nami/Rakan that it has to be used every time the player engages. 

Factually, using these abilities wrong can cause the player to end up wasting her small mana pool. Learning when to use each ability is crucial to a Sona's gameplay. Spamming Q can result in taking significant amounts of damage for very little result and drain her mana quick, especially if they're getting in auto attack range to use the power chord. Spamming W, for obvious reasons, will just drain Sona's mana. The ADC shouldn't be taking so much damage that the Sona feels the need to spam W. That's a fault in the ADC but an even bigger fault in the Sona for wasting the mana when not needed. Using E to engage can result in Sona being trapped when a disengage needed, or it being on cooldown when the power chord is needed. Her E can be used as a form of kiting for the ADC to safely get in more damage.

And the most common error players make is not using the proper power chord in each given situation. They think the damage one is going to be the best in every situation because yay damage! Realistically, the slow power chord is the strongest as, aforementioned, it empowers the ADC's ability to kite/poke safely. The armor shred one can be stronger than the damage one in the sense that Sona can use it and back off safely to avoid the Sona from taking too much damage or potentially dying.

A lot of Sona also has to do with positioning. As squishy as she is, she shouldn't be playing nearly as aggressive as the ADC. And lastly, her ult is a long duration AoE stun, so it should be an ultimate rather than a Q, etc. It's really all about using the right abilities at the right time and positioning properly, like any champion. Sona is unique. Her kit isn't like any other support. Play her like a Sona, not a Thresh/Nami/Lux/Lulu/Rakan.

Source to Sona's Winrate: https://champion.gg/statistics/#?sortBy=general.winPercent&order=descend&roleSort=Support

What I think is hilarious about your post. . .. 

1) Sona has one of the highest win loss ratios in the game right now. Period.  
She's been in one spot or another in the top 5 for the last several months.

2) Sona is the best scaling support, damage wise, period. 
She's border line busted. You can build whatever you want, whatever runes you want, and she still wins. Aery, comet, klepto, dark harvest. . .all of them are good, and all of them work. The ability to build things like ardent censor early, which buffs her damage AND her ally's damage is why she's been dominating. (Not to mention that both Klepto and Dark harvest AP damage bonuses procing) And its not just me saying this. The [data](https://champion.gg/champion/Sona/Support) and [professionals](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eUANXECSQ40) also agree.

3) Sona is not the most mobile of supports, but she's still pretty damn mobile. The AoE speed buff she gives is fantastic, and the fact that she's giving a shield AND an ardent buff on EVERYONE in RANGE with 2 of her 3 main spells is so busted, they're nerfing it on the only champ that does something similar upcoming [rework](https://www.riftherald.com/lol-gameplay/2018/10/24/18019252/karma-rework-kit-update)

4) Sona is an aggressive, high risk, high reward support. . . . the Draven of supports, if you will. You named off a list of supports with their crowd control abilities.  Given she was specifically[ rebalanced](https://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/champion-update/sona-maven-of-the-strings) 4 years ago exactly to THIS play-style, means adding crowd control to any of her base abilities would be like adding wings to a tiger. 

5) Sona and her play-style might not be for you. This is okay. Not every champion is designed for the same type of player. Go play something else.

I feel you have missed my point, though i have bitched about this alot so i forget if i made it clear in this post.

1)  Sona has one of the lowest win-loss ratios in the game during the 0-20 min mark.  This is the data i want focused on.  

2)  The issue is you NEED to build that stuff before she "gets good".  Look at other supports, items help but their kits are still designed to do their thing.  {{champion:16}} heals better with items, but she can still heal pretty decently by pumping points into the skill.

3) Sona is able to really abuse a lot of items and that's great.  Problem is that when you balance a champion around how they can abuse an item, they first have to GET the item.  {{champion:81}} can really abuse {{item:3057}} and that item line, but if he does trash damage until he gets it then you have an issue where he simply doesn't work right for a chunk of the game.  Let's say i rush {{item:3504}} , i'm still probably looking at about 4000 gold spent on items before i get to "abuse" this thing.  4000 gold takes quite a while to get on a support if you aren't getting kills/assists.

4) Sona is a an aggressive high risk, low-ish reward champion for the early game and that is the problem.  40-100 damage with an eight second cooldown (100-160 on a 7.2 if you account for her ult passive between lvl 6-9) is really bad for a champion that needs to be constantly aggressive.


Sona has a great mid and late game, I really enjoy the idea of a hyper carry support.  I just wish her early game wasn't such a drawn out pain to crawl through.

So we clearly disagree on Sona.  But let me pose this differently.  What is Sona suppose to do during lane phase?  does she do that job well?  If no, then at what point does she start doing her job well?

My issue remains that she doesn't really do much of anything during the lane phase against the vast majority of champions.  If she is suppose to be a enhancer support through the entire game, then she needs to have actual enhancer abilities that you can use through out the entire game, not just post 25 mins.

Also i'm not arguing that she needs {{champion:63}} level of damage output, i'm arguing that i really shouldn't be losing a trade with {{champion:40}} or {{champion:17}}  .  I'm arguing that a champion who's kit is based around casting a lot of low impact spells, instead of 1-2 big ones, should be able to cast a lot of spells without needing 40%+ CDR to keep pace.

The last big change they made to her was to add the passive to her ultimate.  They did this specifically because they noted that she wasn't able to keep up given that her abilities are rather weak individually.  I'm simply suggesting maybe take the passive away and just reduce her base cooldowns by 25% (at least on her Q and W).  She keeps the high risk high reward aspect of her kit, gains the means to maintain pressure / Keep her teammate alive during lane phase, and no longer has a late game where she is running around with a possible 67% CDR.

Or if you want her to be more of an enhancer type character maybe give her some half decent freaking enhancement abilities.  Split the difference between her old version and this new one.  Give her the ability to give actual buffs but have them only last for like 4 seconds if you are within a fairly close range to her.  Maybe Q gives flat bonus AD/AP, or lethality while the aura is active.  You know something that might actually help your ally win the lane, instead of a tiny boost of bonus damage that doesn't work on buildings but can still be wasted on a minion.

> Champion Insights
Sona, designed by Fearless

So, let’s get to the why part!

Essentially, we took Sona to the update board because we saw a unique opportunity to make her more rewarding and more fun. She wasn’t terribly strong or weak, but her kit clearly lacked high moments and overall satisfaction. We wanted to keep her theme as it was and retain her awesome Crescendo while giving her basic abilities a more visible and tangible impact. Oh, and if we could sneak in some fancy texture updates in the process (and we could!), then all the better.

So what’s changed? Well, Sona’s gameplay now revolves more around moments of power. Instead of hanging back and winning a war of attrition during laning, Sona’s now got the kit to power up her allies and save their lives when a fight turns against them. Auras are smaller and more visible now, so getting the most of them requires great positional awareness for Sona and coordination with her allies. This allows us to reward great play with much more impact for each of her songs. You’ll be able to make plays as Sona, earn your team kills and save lives with clutch ability casts and smart positioning. At the same time, the enemy team has larger windows to fight back in thanks to her longer cooldowns, adding in clarity and counterplay to Sona’s kit. We can't wait to see what players can do with her update.

...this is a really bad analysis of the role and the champs in it.

That's not a analysis of the role as it exists; now nor is it one of the champions that occupy it. 

So yeah, it's going to be bad at appearing as something that it isn't.

You stating that Thresh and Rakan are "too offensive for the support role" is a pretty shit analysis of those champs, and you saying that their jobs as supports is the antithesis of the support fantasy shows you have a very limited view on what supports should and shouldn't do in the game.

Call me crazy, but I think that supports should probably support in this game. 

Thresh and Rakan don't support, they carry. 

And frankly, I wouldn't care if they existed, if it was possible to have both exist at the same time, but it's simply not. The nature of the game will always bias one of the designs over the other and because the carry play style is appealing to more people than the supporting play style, there's incentive for riot to ensure that the loser of this is the supporting play style. 

Like, if you want a good example of how this has changed, a champion who was released before thresh and reworked after thresh, as a "support" that really demonstrates how they shifted the definition of support to be more aligned with a carrying design like thresh. 
{{champion:43}} 2 years later {{champion:412}} two months later {{champion:43}} rework. 
I'm not saying that Karma was a response to thresh, but it's an indication of how their idea of a "support" changed between her original release and the rework around the same time as thresh. Thresh's success at appealing to a different support role audience is likely what made them keep the change in design long run.
